Now, although I believe that the biology of homosexuality is relevant to gay rights, I don't want to make a hard Darwinian claim for the fitness of homosexuality as an innate trait. There are arguments for and against it. Still, its prevalence in human and other vertebrate species is remarkable, especially for those people who would dearly like to assume that it must have negative fitness. Since it persists despite naive expectations it should be bred out, then either: (1) it has no deleterious consequences for the gene pool within which it resides (it exists just because it can exist), or (2) any deleterious consequences are more than offset by adaptive advantages to kin, or (3) it has a positive selective value. This scientific question is not resolved by any study to date, but it remains an important one.
 
 As a result of scientific study of this question since about the turn of the last century, it makes no sense any more to regard it as "unnatural", or even remotely undesirable or unhealthy. Science has pulled the rug out from under those, popular though they have been in religious circles. The only reason it might be regarded as undesirable today is because it breaks social or religious taboos or expectations, and then the question arises of whether the taboos and expectations are more important than the well-being of gay human beings.
 
 Now, it's up to those with a social or religious bias against gay people to justify it, and the only way they can do so is not by quoting, misquoting, or selectively excerpting their holy scriptures, but by demonstrating the harm caused by allowing gay people to live in peace and mutual respect with straight people.
